questions.text: Which of the typhoidal Salmonella is most likely to cause pyogenic abscess formation during enteric fever?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • S paratyphi C is the most virulent among paratyphoid strains
  • Uniquely associated with suppurative complications such as pyogenic abscess formation
  • More likely to cause localized infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals

Explanation of other options:

S. typhi (Option A): Causes classical enteric fever with mononuclear inflammation and ulceration, typically without abscess formation

S. paratyphi A (Option B): Produces a milder systemic illness, not known for deep tissue invasion or abscess formation

S. paratyphi B (Option C): Clinically similar to S. paratyphi A, low virulence, and not associated with suppurative complications

Key Takeaways:

  • S. paratyphi C can cause pyogenic abscesses during enteric fever
  • Other typhoidal Salmonella species cause systemic illness but not localized suppuration
  • Strain-specific virulence guides clinical complications

questions.text: The primary site of chronic carriage for Salmonella is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Salmonella Typhi establishes chronic carriage by forming biofilms on cholesterol gallstones
  • The gallbladder provides a stable niche for long-term colonization
  • Chronic carriage is strongly linked to an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma

Explanation of other options:

Urinary Bladder (Option A): Can be secondarily infected but is not a primary site of chronic carriage.

Rectum (Option B): May be involved in intermittent fecal shedding, not chronic colonization

Intestinal lymph nodes (Option D): Play a role in immune processing, not in long-term bacterial carriage

Key Takeaways:

  • The gallbladder is the key reservoir for chronic Salmonella Typhi carriage
  • Biofilm formation on gallstones enables persistent infection
  • Chronic carriers are at higher risk for gallbladder cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is not common in primary pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cavity formation requires caseating necrosis with drainage into airways, which generates an air-filled space in the lung parenchyma
  • This process depends on a delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) response, which is not well developed in primary TB
  • Primary pulmonary tuberculosis occurs in individuals without prior exposure, typically children or immunologically naive adults
  • The bacilli are inhaled and settle in the middle or lower lobes, where the Ghon focus forms a granulomatous lesion surrounded by mononuclear cells
  • The bacilli spread via lymphatics to regional hilar or mediastinal lymph nodes, producing the Ghon complex, which is a classic finding in primary TB (Option C ruled out)
  • If the Ghon focus is subpleural, it may irritate the pleura and lead to a pleural effusion, especially in adolescents and young adults (Option D ruled out)
  • As the immune response contains the infection, the lesion undergoes fibrosis and dystrophic calcification, which may be seen as a radiopaque nodule years later (Option B ruled out)
  • In contrast, post-primary TB, occurring in previously sensitized adults, is when cavitation is common, especially in the upper lobes due to higher oxygen tension and stronger immune response

Key Takeaways:

  • Cavitary lesions are typical of post-primary TB, not primary TB
  • Ghon complex, pleural effusion, and fibrotic calcified nodules are characteristic of primary TB
  • Host immune maturity determines the pattern of TB pathology

questions.text: A HIV positive man presented with a nonproductive cough, fever, and dyspnea. Chest examination is normal. He had a history of TB contact. Which of the following tests would be helpful in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HRCT thorax is the most sensitive imaging modality for evaluating pulmonary TB and opportunistic infections in HIV-positive patients, especially when the chest exam is normal and symptoms are nonspecific
  • It can detect subtle findings, such as miliary nodules, interstitial infiltrates, or pleural effusions, which are often missed on plain radiographs.
  • Sputum culture enables microbiological confirmation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and detects non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), which are common in immunocompromised individuals.
  • It also facilitates drug sensitivity testing, important in high TB-burden regions.

Explanation of other options:

Interferon Gamma Release Assay (Option B): Useful for latent TB, not appropriate for diagnosing active TB, especially in HIV due to poor sensitivity

Tuberculin Skin Test (Option C): Low accuracy in HIV due to anergy, with potential false negatives and cross-reactivity

Key Takeaways:

  • HRCT detects subtle or atypical pulmonary disease in immunocompromised patients
  • Sputum culture is necessary for diagnosing active TB and NTM
  • TST and IGRA are unreliable in active TB workup for HIV patients

choices.text: Assume rifampicin resistance coexisting with isoniazid and start the DOTS plus regimen.
Substitute isoniazid with levofloxacin in category I treatment for 6 months.

questions.text: A patient had pulmonary TB and was started on isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. A few days later, his DST report showed Isoniazid resistance. Which of the following is the right treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has confirmed isoniazid monoresistant TB (H mono/poly DR-TB) on drug susceptibility testing, while rifampicin remains sensitive
  • In such cases, the standard recommendation is to replace isoniazid with levofloxacin
  • The appropriate 6-month regimen includes:
    • Levofloxacin (Lfx)
    • Rifampicin (R)
    • Ethambutol (E)
    • Pyrazinamide (Z)
  • This regimen effectively treats drug-resistant TB without escalating to MDR protocols unnecessarily.

Explanation of other options:

Assume rifampicin resistance and start DOTS Plus (Option A): DOTS Plus is indicated only in confirmed rifampicin-resistant TB, assuming resistance leads to unwarranted toxic regimens.

Category I treatment for 6 months (Option B): Continues isoniazid, which is ineffective here, risking treatment failure and resistance amplification

Category I treatment (Option D): Lacks regimen adjustment for documented isoniazid resistance

Key Takeaways:

  • H mono/poly DR-TB should be treated with Lfx, R, E, Z for 6 months
  • Never escalate to MDR regimens without rifampicin resistance confirmation
  • Individualized regimens based on DST improve outcomes and prevent misuse of second-line drugs

questions.text: Which of the following drugs make up the FDA-approved BPaL regimen used in the treatment of XDR-TB and treatment-intolerant MDR-TB?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BPaL regimen is a fixed 3-drug combination consisting of:
    • Bedaquiline (Bdq)
    • Pretomanid (Pa)
    • Linezolid (Lzd)
  • This regimen was FDA-approved in August 2019 for the treatment of:
    • Extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB)
    • Pre-XDR TB (resistance to isoniazid, rifampin, and a fluoroquinolone or injectable drug)
    • Treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive MDR-TB
  • It is used when a safe and effective alternative regimen cannot be constructed
  • Pretomanid is given at 200 mg daily for 26 weeks, alongside the other two agents

Explanation of other options:

Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Levofloxacin (Option B): Incorrect levofloxacin is not part of the BPaL regimen

Bedaquiline, PAS, Linezolid (Option C): Incorrect, PAS (para-aminosalicylic acid) is not included in BPaL

Bedaquiline, PAS, Levofloxacin (Option D): Incorrect contains neither pretomanid nor linezolid, both of which are essential to BPaL

Key Takeaways:

  • BPaL = Bedaquiline + Pretomanid + Linezolid
  • Used in XDR-TB, pre-XDR-TB, and nonresponsive MDR-TB
  • Regimen is reserved for cases where no other safe, effective regimen is available

questions.text: Most common complication of pneumococcal pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Empyema is the most common focal complication of pneumococcal pneumonia, occurring in less than 5% of cases
  • It typically develops after 4-5 days of antibiotic therapy, when fever and leukocytosis persist despite treatment
  • Empyema is a purulent pleural effusion with either:
    • Frank pus
    • Positive bacterial microscopy
    • Pleural fluid pH ≤ 7.1
  • Management requires aggressive drainage, usually with a chest tube
  • Though parapneumonic effusions are more common, they are usually non-purulent and self-limited

Explanation of other options:

Meningitis (Option B): A serious complication of pneumococcal infection, but not typically associated with pneumonia itself

Sinusitis (Option C): Common in pneumococcal disease but unrelated to pneumonia as a complication

Otitis media (Option D): More common in children and as a primary illness, not a complication of pneumonia

Key Takeaways:

  • Empyema is the most frequent localized complication of pneumococcal pneumonia
  • Requires prompt drainage if suspected
  • Differentiate parapneumonic effusion from true empyema based on clinical course and pleural fluid findings.

questions.text: Non-hemolytic Enterococcus causes
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enterococcus, particularly E. faecalis and E. faecium, are non-hemolytic Gram-positive cocci that colonize the gastrointestinal tract. They are notable for causing nosocomial infections, most commonly urinary tract infections (UTIs). Risk factors include catheterization, structural urinary tract abnormalities, and broad-spectrum antibiotic use. Their ability to adhere to uroepithelial surfaces and form biofilms contributes to persistent infection.

Explanation of other options:

Pharyngitis (Option B): Most commonly caused by Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) enterococci are not implicated.

Neonatal sepsis (Option C): Typically due to Group B Streptococcus, E. coli, or Listeria monocytogenes. Enterococcus is a rare cause.

Meningitis (Option D): Rarely caused by enterococci, usually occurring in immunocompromised patients or after neurosurgical procedures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Non-hemolytic enterococci are primary agents in nosocomial UTIs.
  • They are part of the GI flora and exhibit broad antibiotic resistance.
  • Other conditions listed are not commonly associated with enterococci.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for the diagnosis of enteric fever?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most sensitive diagnostic method for enteric fever is culture of intestinal secretions, which can yield S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi even when other cultures (blood or bone marrow) are negative. The duodenal string test is a non-invasive method that collects intestinal secretions and can detect organisms present in higher quantities due to the gastrointestinal localization of the bacteria. Studies have shown that this method can yield positive results even in cases where bone marrow cultures are negative, making it the most sensitive test overall.

Bone marrow culture is often considered the gold standard in clinical practice due to its high yield (>80%), especially when antibiotic pretreatment is present, but it still may miss some cases that intestinal secretion culture would detect.

Explanation of other options:

Blood culture (Option A): Sensitivity is variable (40-80%) and is highly affected by prior antibiotic use. Organisms are present in low numbers in blood and often sequestered in the buffy coat, making this test less sensitive than intestinal secretion or bone marrow culture.

Bone marrow culture (Option B): Though highly sensitive (>80%) and not significantly affected by prior antibiotic use for up to 5 days, it still may miss cases that are detectable in intestinal secretions. Therefore, it is not the most sensitive.

Widal test (Option D): This is a serologic test, not a culture method. It is neither specific nor sensitive and is not recommended for diagnosis due to widespread false positives in endemic areas and a lack of standardization.

Key Takeaways:

  • Intestinal secretion culture is the most sensitive test, especially using the duodenal string method.
  • Bone marrow culture is the next best and highly reliable, even after antibiotic therapy.
  • Blood culture is limited by organism load and prior antibiotic use.
  • The Widal test is obsolete for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Most common site for tuberculous lymphadenitis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tuberculous lymphadenitis is the most common form of extrapulmonary TB, especially in HIV-positive individuals and children.
  • The posterior cervical lymph nodes are most commonly involved, followed by supraclavicular nodes this presentation is classically known as scrofula.
  • It presents as painless, slowly progressive lymph node swelling, which may eventually fistulize.
  • Most cases today are caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (not bovis).

Explanation of other options:

Infraclavicular (Option B) - Rarely involved in TB not a typical site of tuberculous lymphadenitis.

Jugulodigastric (Option C) - More commonly affected in bacterial pharyngitis and tonsillitis, not in TB.

Submandibular (Option D) - Can be involved but less frequently than posterior cervical more typical in dental infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • Posterior cervical lymph nodes are the most frequently affected in tuberculous lymphadenitis.
  • Scrofula refers to TB of cervical lymph nodes, usually painless and chronic.
  • High prevalence in HIV-infected individuals and children.

questions.text: A tree-in-bud appearance is seen in the CT chest of pneumonia caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "tree-in-bud" appearance on high-resolution CT is a classic radiological pattern representing endobronchial spread of infection, especially involving centrilobular nodules with linear branching opacities.
  • This pattern is highly characteristic of Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection, particularly in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., HIV with low CD4).
  • It results from bronchiolar impaction by inflammatory exudate or caseating necrosis that extends into the airways, giving the characteristic "tree with budding branches" look.

Explanation of other options:

Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B) - This typically causes interstitial infiltrates or peribronchial thickening but does not cause the tree-in-bud pattern. It lacks endobronchial dissemination.

Pneumococcus (Option C) - Causes lobar consolidation with air bronchograms and often does not show a tree-in-bud appearance. It is a classic cause of community-acquired pneumonia with an alveolar pattern.

Chlamydia pneumoniae (Option D) - Causes atypical pneumonia with diffuse patchy infiltrates, usually without cavitation or tree-in-bud appearance.

Key takeaways:

  • The tree-in-bud pattern on HRCT chest suggests endobronchial spread, most commonly due to Mycobacterium avium complex and other mycobacterial infections.
  • Seen frequently in immunocompromised patients, including those with HIV/AIDS.
  • Recognizing this radiological sign helps differentiate infectious etiologies with airway-centric disease.

questions.text: Peribronchial pneumonia is typically seen in chest radiographs. It is caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peribronchial pneumonia shows inflammation and thickening around bronchi and bronchioles, visible as peribronchial cuffing on imaging.
  • This pattern is most classically caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, a frequent cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in young adults and school-aged children.
  • Imaging may reveal reticulonodular infiltrates, peribronchial opacities, or patchy ground-glass changes, while clinical symptoms remain relatively mild.

Explanation of other options:

Mycobacterium avium (Option A): Causes tree-in-bud appearance on CT due to endobronchial spread, not peribronchial thickening.

Pneumococcus (Option C): Typically produces lobar consolidation with air bronchograms, not a peribronchial pattern.

Chlamydia pneumoniae (Option D): Can cause atypical pneumonia but is more often associated with patchy infiltrates, not classic peribronchial thickening.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of peribronchial pneumonia in young patients.
  • Imaging shows peribronchial cuffing, often out of proportion to mild clinical symptoms.
  • It is classified as an atypical pneumonia, and macrolides or doxycycline are preferred treatments.

questions.text: All are true about the radiological findings in the spine of a brucellosis patient except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior wedge Not typical of brucellar spondylitis. Wedge collapse and vertebral body destruction are more characteristic of tuberculous spondylitis (Pott disease), often leading to gibbus deformity. In brucellosis, the vertebral body remains morphologically intact until late stages. Hence, this is the correct answer (i.e., the incorrect statement).

Key Takeaways:

  • Brucellosis: lumbar spine, multiple vertebrae, late discitis, vertebral body preserved.
  • Tuberculosis: dorsolumbar spine, early discitis, wedge collapse, gibbus deformity.
  • Anterior wedge deformity is not typical of brucellosis, helping distinguish it from TB.

choices.text: Levels of plasma HIV RNA decrease in the setting of active TB.
TB usually develops only when the median CD4 count is 200/L.
Extrapulmonary disease is more common than pulmonary disease in the HIV-infected individual.
Therapy for TB is the same in the HIV-infected patient as in the HIV-negative patient.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the relationship of tuberculosis (TB) and HIV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the United States, up to 5% of patients with AIDS have active TB, most often presenting with pulmonary disease
  • Pulmonary TB remains more common than extrapulmonary TB, though disseminated forms become more frequent as CD4 counts fall.
  • TB increases plasma HIV RNA levels due to immune activation, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and treatment in HIV-positive individuals.
  • Skin testing (e.g., tuberculin skin test) helps identify latent TB but is not reliable for diagnosing active TB in immunocompromised patients.
  • Active typical TB can develop even in early HIV infection at relatively high CD4 counts, unlike atypical mycobacteria (like MAC), which appear later.
  • Patients with higher CD4 counts often show typical reactivation TB with apical cavitary lesions, fever, weight loss, cough, and dyspnea.
  • In advanced immunosuppression, TB presents more often as disseminated or extrapulmonary disease.
  • Standard anti-TB therapy (isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) remains effective.
  • Rifabutin should replace rifampin when the patient is on protease inhibitors or NNRTIs due to cytochrome P450 interaction.s

Explanation of other options:

Levels of plasma HIV RNA decrease in the setting of active TB (Option A): This is incorrect. Active TB increases systemic immune activation, leading to higher HIV viral replication and elevated plasma RNA levels.

TB usually develops only when the median CD4 count is 200/μL (Option B): This is incorrect. TB can occur at any stage of HIV infection, including relatively early, when CD4 counts are still high.

Extrapulmonary disease is more common than pulmonary disease in the HIV-infected individual (Option C): This is incorrect. Pulmonary TB is still more common overall, though extrapulmonary manifestations rise as CD4 counts fall.

Key Takeaways:

TB can develop early in HIV, even at high CD4 counts

Pulmonary TB is more common than extrapulmonary TB in most HIV patients

Standard TB therapy applies in HIV, with rifabutin substituted to avoid ART interactions

questions.text: A 23-year-old man who lives with his male partner consults you for an opinion. He has suffered from anal discharge and pruritus for the past 3 days. There are also some symptoms of dysuria. A urethral smear reveals intracellular diplococci. What is the most likely infectious agent to fit with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows polymorphonuclear neutrophils containing intracellular, kidney bean-shaped diplococci, which are diagnostic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Gonorrhea is a gram-negative diplococcal STI that frequently causes urethritis, proctitis, or pharyngitis, depending on exposure.e
  • In men, it often presents with purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, and in MSM, rectal symptoms like pruritus and discharge.e
  • Gram stain of urethral exudate is highly sensitive and specific in symptomatic males intracellular diplococci confirm the diagnosis.s
  • Treatment is with ceftriaxone 500 mg IM plus doxycycline or azithromycin if chlamydia has not been excluded.
  • Patients should also be screened for co-infections, especially chlamydia, syphilis, and HIV.

Explanation of other options:

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B): This is incorrect. Chlamydia is not seen on Gram stains and does not appear as diplococci. It causes urethritis but lacks visible organisms on smear.

Treponema pallidum (Option C): This is incorrect. T. pallidum is a spirochete, not seen on Gram stains, and causes painless genital ulcers. Diagnosis requires serology or dark-field microscopy.

Herpes simplex-type 1 (Option D): This is incorrect. HSV-1 can cause genital ulcers but does not cause intracellular diplococci or purulent urethral discharge. Diagnosis is via PCR or Tzanck smear.

Key Takeaways:

  • Intracellular gram-negative diplococci on smear = Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Gonorrhea presents with purulent urethral or rectal discharge in MSM
  • Always screen and empirically treat for chlamydia unless excluded

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with chlamydia pneumonia. What is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chlamydia pneumoniae is an atypical intracellular respiratory pathogen, not responsive to beta-lactam antibiotics like ampicillin or cephalosporins
  • The preferred treatment includes macrolides such as clarithromycin or azithromycin, which achieve high intracellular concentrations.
  • Diagnosis is difficult and often clinical, as culturing the organism requires tissue culture, and serology is often unreliable.
  • Empiric therapy is typically given when atypical pneumonia is suspected, especially in young adults with mild-to-moderate respiratory illness.

Explanation of other options:

Ampicillin (Option A): This is incorrect. Ampicillin is ineffective against intracellular organisms like Chlamydia pneumoniae because it does not penetrate cells well and does not target atypical pathogens.

Imipenem (Option C): This is incorrect. Imipenem is a broad-spectrum carbapenem effective against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but not typically used for atypical pathogens like Chlamydia pneumoniae.

Cefuroxime (Option D): This is incorrect. Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin that lacks activity against atypical organisms and is not useful for treating Chlamydia pneumoniae.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chlamydia pneumoniae is an atypical intracellular pathogen
  • Macrolides are the drug of choice due to their excellent intracellular penetration
  • Diagnosis is often clinical empiric treatment is appropriate

choices.text: He needs treatment for tuberculosis, and his close contacts need screening, but he is not infectious to casual contacts.
He needs treatment for tuberculosis, his close contacts need screening, and he needs to be isolated from casual contacts.
He needs treatment for tuberculosis, but he is not infectious to close or casual contacts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with a productive cough. Sputum is smear-positive for tuberculosis. What does this mean?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Smear-positive TB indicates a high burden of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in the sputum and correlates with high infectivity
  • Patients with smear-positive TB are infectious to both close contacts (e.g., household members) and casual contacts (e.g., healthcare workers, ward mates)
  • He should be treated immediately and placed in a negative-pressure isolation room until he has completed at least 2 weeks of effective therapy, by which time infectivity typically drops.
  • Particulate respirator masks (e.g., N95) should be worn by healthcare workers during contact.
  • Although the sputum smear may remain positive after 2 weeks, the bacilli are usually non-viable by then.
  • Smear positivity does not confirm multidrug resistance or HIV infection

Explanation of other options:

He needs treatment for tuberculosis and his close contacts need screening, but he is not infectious to casual contacts (Option A): This is incorrect. Smear-positive TB is highly infectious to both close and casual contacts, especially in indoor or hospital settings.

He needs treatment for tuberculosis, but he is not infectious to close or casual contacts (Option C): This is incorrect. Smear-positive status signifies active, transmissible disease. He is infectious to others.

He has multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (Option D): This is incorrect. Smear positivity indicates high bacterial load, but not drug resistance. Resistance must be confirmed via culture and sensitivity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Smear-positive TB = highly infectious to close and casual contacts
  • Requires isolation and particulate mask precautions until treatment reduces infectivity
  • Smear status does not imply drug resistance or HIV

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed as having epidemic typhus. By which vector is he most likely to have become infected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis)
  • The louse becomes infected by feeding on the blood of a person with typhus it then excretes rickettsiae in its feces near the bite site.
  • Infection occurs when the person scratches the bite, introducing the pathogen into the skin.
  • Epidemic typhus is associated with overcrowding, poor hygiene, and occurs in situations like wars, refugee camps, and prisons.

Explanation of other options:

Hard tick (Option A): This is incorrect. Hard ticks transmit Rocky Mountain spotted fever and rickettsialpox, not epidemic typhus.

Trombiculid mite (Option C): This is incorrect. Larval trombiculid mites (chiggers) transmit scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Aedes aegypti mosquito (Option D): This is incorrect. Aedes aegypti transmits dengue, Zika, yellow fever, and chikungunya, not rickettsial infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • Epidemic typhus is transmitted by the human body louse
  • It is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, typically in settings of overcrowding and poor sanitation
  • Other vectors transmit different forms of typhus and arboviral diseases

questions.text: Human-to-human transmission of nontuberculous mycobacteria infection occurs almost exclusively in patients with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are environmental organisms found in soil, water, and various artificial sources such as aquifers and metalworking fluids
  • They rarely spread from person to person, except in a very specific population: patients with cystic fibrosis, who are uniquely vulnerable due to chronic lung damage and bronchiectasis.
  • Human-to-human transmission has been documented in cystic fibrosis treatment centers, likely via shared airspaces or contaminated equipment.
  • In other populations, NTM infections are typically acquired from the environment through inhalation or direct inoculation.

Explanation of other options:

HIV (Option A): This is incorrect. HIV patients are susceptible to disseminated NTM (especially Mycobacterium avium complex) due to immunosuppression, but transmission is environmental, not human-to-human.

Diabetes mellitus (Option C): This is incorrect. Diabetics are not uniquely at increased risk of NTM transmission, and person-to-person spread does not occur in this group.

Ventilatory support (Option D): This is incorrect. While ventilated patients are at risk for hospital-acquired infections, NTM are not typically transmitted from human to human, even in ICU settings.

Key Takeaways:

  • Human-to-human transmission of NTM is extremely rare and occurs almost exclusively in cystic fibrosis patients
  • Most NTM infections are acquired from the environment, not from other individuals
  • Cystic fibrosis creates a unique niche for sustained colonization and spread of NTM

questions.text: Most common organism causing overwhelming infection in post-splenectomy patients is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common and most dangerous organism causing overwhelming postsplenectomy infection (OPSI) is Streptococcus pneumoniae, a capsulated, gram-positive diplococcus
  • The spleen plays a crucial role in clearing encapsulated bacteria via opsonization and phagocytosis, especially in children and immunocompromised adults
  • Loss of splenic function predisposes patients to rapidly progressive, fulminant sepsis, often due to pneumoniae, which accounts for the majority of cases of OPSI
  • These infections can progress within hours and are associated with high mortality if not treated immediately
  • Patients require lifelong pneumococcal vaccination and often prophylactic antibiotics

Explanation of other options:

Haemophilus influenzae (Option A): This is incorrect. It is another encapsulated organism and a known cause of sepsis post-splenectomy, but it is less common than S. pneumoniae.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option C): This is incorrect. Although it can cause severe infections, it is not typically linked to OPSI in asplenic patients.

Neisseria meningitidis (Option D): This is incorrect. It is a significant encapsulated pathogen and a cause of meningococcal sepsis, but S. pneumoniae remains the most common agent of overwhelming sepsis in asplenic individuals.

Key Takeaways:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the leading cause of overwhelming infection in asplenic patients
  • Encapsulated organisms pose the greatest risk in the absence of splenic immune clearance
  • Preventive vaccination and education are essential in all splenectomized individuals

questions.text: Which of the following is the best intervention to be carried out to prove rheumatic etiology in a girl who comes with Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever is suspected. Other major criteria of rheumatic fever are absent, there is no evidence of a sore throat?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sydenham's chorea is a major Jones criterion and often appears 3-6 months after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis
  • By the time chorea develops, the sore throat may be forgotten, and throat cultures or rapid antigen tests are usually negative
  • Therefore, the best intervention to establish rheumatic etiology is to demonstrate a preceding streptococcal infection using serologic evidence, particularly anti-streptolysin O (ASLO) titers, which remain elevated for weeks to months after infection
  • Even in the absence of other major criteria or a remembered sore throat, a raised ASLO titer supports a post-streptococcal autoimmune process consistent with acute rheumatic fever

Explanation of other options:

Anti-DNase B (Option A): This is incorrect. While also used to detect prior streptococcal infection, ASLO is more commonly used and more standardized in the context of acute rheumatic fever, especially for Sydenham's chorea.

Throat culture (Option C): This is incorrect. Throat cultures are typically negative by the time chorea develops, as the initial infection occurred months earlier.

Blood culture (Option D): This is incorrect. Rheumatic fever is a post-infectious autoimmune condition and is not associated with bacteremia.

Key Takeaways:

  • ASLO titer is the most appropriate test to confirm prior streptococcal infection in Sydenham's chorea
  • Throat cultures are usually negative due to delayed presentation
  • Anti-DNase B may also be elevated but is not the first-line choice in this setting

choices.text: Dapsone 100 mg/day (unsupervised) + Rifampin 600 mg/month(supervised) for 6 months
Dapsone + clofazimine [unsupervised] and rifampicin + clofazimine [supervised] for 1-2 year

questions.text: Which of the following would be the recommended regimen for paucibacillary leprosy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paucibacillary leprosy is defined as 1-5 skin lesions with no detectable bacilli on slit-skin smear
  • WHO recommends multidrug therapy for 6 months: Dapsone 100 mg/day (unsupervised) and Rifampin 600 mg/month (supervised)
  • This regimen minimizes resistance, ensures adherence, and is cost-effective
  • Multibacillary leprosy (more than 5 lesions or smear-positive) requires clofazimine and treatment for 12 months or more

Explanation of other options:

Dapsone + clofazimine [unsupervised] and rifampicin + clofazimine [supervised] for 1-2 years (Option B): This is incorrect. This is the multibacillary regimen, not appropriate for paucibacillary cases.

Dapsone 100 mg/day for 5 years (Option C): This is incorrect. This outdated monotherapy has been replaced due to high rates of resistance and relapse.

Indefinite treatment (Option D): This is incorrect. Leprosy treatment is always time-bound and tailored based on clinical form indefinite treatment is never recommended.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paucibacillary leprosy requires 6-month treatment with dapsone and rifampin
  • Clofazimine is added only in multibacillary cases
  • WHO regimens are age-adjusted and designed for fixed durations

questions.text:
Which of the following is this skin lesion seen in?

Select one option
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tuberculoid leprosy presents with one or a few hypopigmented macules or plaques that are sharply demarcated
  • These lesions often have raised erythematous borders, are hypoesthetic, dry, scaly, and anhidrotic due to destruction of cutaneous nerves and glands
  • The lesions are typically devoid of sweat glands or hair follicles, which leads to their classic texture and appearance
  • AFB are generally absent or very scanty in these lesions
  • Common presentations include:
    • a) Hypochromic macule on face
    • b) Annular plaque on right arm
    • c) Hypochromic plaque on left knee with infiltrated low edge
    • d) Multiple large hypochromic macules on the trunk


Explanation of other options:

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option B): This is incorrect. It presents with multiple, poorly defined symmetric lesions, often nodular or shiny, with diffuse involvement. AFB are numerous.

Erythema Nodosum (Option C): This is incorrect. Erythema nodosum presents with tender, erythematous nodules, especially over shins, not hypopigmented annular plaques.

Lupus pernio (Option D): This is incorrect. Seen in sarcoidosis, lupus pernio causes violaceous, indurated plaques or nodules, usually over the nose, cheeks, lips, or ears, not the chest or trunk.

Key Takeaways:

Tuberculoid leprosy features well-defined, hypopigmented, hypoesthetic plaques with sensory loss

Lesions are dry, hairless, and anhidrotic due to nerve involvement

AFB are typically absent or scanty in tuberculoid leprosy
